citation.article-title: Hansschlegelia plantiphila gen. nov. sp. nov., a new aerobic restricted facultative methylotrophic bacterium associated with plants

p.s: Description of Hansschlegelia gen. nov.

Hansschlegelia (Hans.schle.ge’li.a M.L. fem. n. Hansschlegelia of Hans schlegel; named after the famous German microbiologist, Professor Hans G. Schlegel, known for his classic studies on autotrophic bacteria).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-sporulating, colorless, non-motile short rods that occur singly or in pairs and multiply by binary fission.
Colonies on mineral salts/methanol agar are white, translucent, convex, round, 0.1–0.5 mm in diameter.
Obligate aerobes, having a strict respiratory type of metabolism with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.
Reduce nitrates to nitrites.
Grow very poorly on nutrient agar and peptone–yeast extract–glucose (PYG) agar.
Restricted facultative methylotrophs and chemolithotrophs.
Assimilate C1 compounds via the RuBP pathway and slightly by the serine pathway.
Utilize only several polycarbon substrates.
Growth occurs on mineral salt medium with a gas mixture of H2/O2/CO2, methanol, methylamine, formate and glycerol.
Growth factors are not required, but biotin and yeast extract have a stimulatory effect.
Nitrogen sources include methylamine, amino acids, ammonium salts and nitrates.
Methyl red and Voges–Proskauer negative.
Urease, catalase and oxidase positive.
Able to form indole from l-tryptophan on mineral medium with methanol as the sole carbon and energy source and with KNO3 as a nitrogen source.
Neutrophilic and mesophilic.
Growth at pH 5.0–9.0 and between temperatures of 12 and 37 °C.
No growth in the presence of 2% NaCl (w/v).
The major ubiquinone is Q-10.
Dominant phospholipids are phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylcholine and diphosphatidylglycerol (cardiolipin).
The prevailing cellular fatty acids are cis-vaccenic (C18:1ω7), palmitic (C16:0) and cyclopropane (C19:0 cyclo) acids.
The genus Hansschlegelia belongs to the alpha-2-subgroup of the Proteobacteria, as revealed by comparative sequence analysis of the 16S rDNA.
The type species is H. plantiphila.
